lenses","slug":"contact-lenses","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/361085"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=361085"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=361085"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=361085"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=361085"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576728636,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/mojo-vision\/","name":"mojo vision","slug":"mojo-vision","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576728636"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576728636"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576728636"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576728636"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576728636"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291585,"date":"2022-03-30T11:50:33","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T18:50:33","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291585"},"modified":"2022-03-30T11:48:13","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T18:48:13","slug":"legendary-hackers-charlie-miller-and-chris-valasek-talk-cybersecurity-and-autonomous-vehicles-at-tc-sessions-mobility-2022","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/legendary-hackers-charlie-miller-and-chris-valasek-talk-cybersecurity-and-autonomous-vehicles-at-tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/","title":{"rendered":"Legendary hackers Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek talk cybersecurity and autonomous vehicles at TC Sessions: Mobility 2022"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Security researchers Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek shook the automotive industry in 2015 by remotely hacking a Jeep Cherokee <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=MK0SrxBC1xs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">driven by Wired reporter<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, and willing participant, Andy Greenberg. The notorious hack caused Fiat Chrysler, Jeep\u2019s parent company, to <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2015\/07\/25\/business\/fiat-chrysler-recalls-1-4-million-vehicles-to-fix-hacking-issue.html?_r=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">recall 1.4 million vehicles<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> and pay <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.freep.com\/story\/money\/2015\/07\/27\/fiat-chrysler-nhtsa-fine-recalls\/30693265\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">$105 million in fines<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> to the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The warning might have been a wake-up call to the industry, but it didn\u2019t slow the rise of the connected car.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Today, the \u201cconnected car\u201d is commonplace and delivers a long list of services to the driver and passengers, from internet connectivity and vehicle monitoring to safety warnings and the ability to buy goods and services while on the go. And it has crept beyond the passenger vehicle into the emerging autonomous vehicle industry, too.\u00a0<\/span><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291585\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Perhaps it\u2019s not surprising then that automotive cyberattacks have grown in frequency \u2014 up <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/itthub.net\/the-bigger-picture\/automation\/increasingly-sophisticated-cyber-attacks-threaten-connected-vehicles\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">more than 225% in 2021<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, compared to 2018. It\u2019s a trend that has caused a boon in the automotive cybersecurity market, which is <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.marketsandmarkets.com\/Market-Reports\/cyber-security-automotive-industry-market-170885898.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">predicted to reach $5.3 billion in 2026<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This is why we\u2019re thrilled to announce that Miller and Valasek \u2014 undisputed leaders in the industry who both hold top security roles at GM\u2019s self-driving vehicle subsidiary Cruise \u2014 will <\/span><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">join us onstage at <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Sessions: Mobility 2022<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> to discuss the dynamic and rapidly changing realm of automotive cybersecurity. The two-day event is scheduled for May 18 and May 19 in San Mateo, California, and will feature the best and brightest minds building and investing in the future of transportation.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A distinguished security engineer, Miller \u2014 whom Foreign Policy called &#8220;one of the most technically proficient hackers on Earth&#8221; \u2014 designs and implements cybersecurity features for the company&#8217;s autonomous vehicles.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Prior to joining Cruise, Miller served as a computer hacker at the National Security Agency, and he consulted and worked for the computer security teams at Twitter, Uber ATG and Didi Chuxing.<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As the director of security engineering at Cruise, Valasek oversees vehicle, infrastructure and application security. He also has extensive experience in reverse engineering and exploitation research. Prior to joining Cruise, Valasek served as security lead at Uber and earlier as the director of vehicle security research at IOActive.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Don\u2019t miss a wide-ranging conversation about the road that led Miller and Valasek from that Jeep Cherokee to Cruise, what needs to happen before the public trusts driverless vehicles, the type of threats they\u2019re seeing, industry trends and what they\u2019ve learned since 2015.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/?utm_medium=tc_article_14&amp;utm_campaign=mobility2022&amp;utm_content=tc_article_14&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=tcarticle14&amp;display=\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">TC Sessions: Mobility 2022<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> breaks through the hype and goes beyond the headlines to discover how merging technology and transportation will affect a broad swath of industries, cities and the people who work and live in them. <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/?utm_medium=tc_article_14&amp;utm_campaign=mobility2022&amp;utm_content=tc_article_14&amp;utm_source=techcrunch&amp;promo=tcarticle14#tickets\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Register today before prices increase April 1<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">!<\/span><\/p>\n<p>\t<iframe\n\t\t\tid=\"wpcom-iframe-6b0e19ca7a929b71d07083f03357bfcd\"\n\t\t\twidth=\"99%\"\n\t\t\theight=\"1000\"\n\t\t\tsrc=\"https:\/\/tcprotectedembed.com\/protected-iframe\/6b0e19ca7a929b71d07083f03357bfcd\"\n\t\t\tscrolling=\"true\"\n\t\t\tframeborder=\"0\"\n\t\t\tclass=\"Bizzabo\"\n\t>\n\t<\/iframe>\n\t<script 2022","slug":"techcrunch-sessions-mobility-2022","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576983674"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576983674"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576983674"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576983674"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576983674"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[{"id":576980503,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/event-type\/sessions\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/","name":"TC Sessions: Mobility 2022","slug":"tc-sessions-mobility-2022","taxonomy":"tc_event","rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/576980503"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_event"}],"up":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_event\/449559507"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_event=576980503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_events?tc_event=576980503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tc_event=576980503"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}]]}},{"id":2291669,"date":"2022-03-30T11:46:37","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T18:46:37","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291669"},"modified":"2022-03-30T13:37:35","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T20:37:35","slug":"youtube-may-be-getting-a-dedicated-podcasts-homepage-audio-ads-and-podcaster-metrics","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/youtube-may-be-getting-a-dedicated-podcasts-homepage-audio-ads-and-podcaster-metrics\/","title":{"rendered":"YouTube may be getting a dedicated podcasts homepage"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">There were already several hints that YouTube was getting more serious about podcasts, after reports indicated the company <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2021\/10\/26\/22746466\/youtube-podcasting-kai-chuk-amazon-project-mic-live-audio-hot-pod\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hired a podcast executive<\/a>, Kai Chuk, to lead its efforts in the space and had <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-03-04\/youtube-offers-up-to-300-000-to-get-podcasters-to-make-videos\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">even begun offering cash<\/a> to popular podcasters to film their shows. Now, a leaked document has unveiled more about YouTube&#8217;s plans in this area, pointing to a future podcasts homepage on YouTube.com and other monetization features.<\/p>\n<p>The details were <a href=\"https:\/\/podnews.net\/update\/youtube-podcasting-plans\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">published by Podnews<\/a>, which recently got its hands on an 84-page presentation where YouTube described its podcasts roadmap. Here, the company says it will improve podcast ingestion by piloting the ability to pull in podcast RSS feeds. It also noted it plans to centralize podcasts on a new homepage at YouTube.com\/podcasts. The URL doesn&#8217;t yet work; but it also doesn&#8217;t automatically redirect to the YouTube homepage &#8212; which is what it does if you put other random words after the slash.<\/p>\n<p>Not surprisingly, Google sees podcasts as a way to expand its advertising business on YouTube. The document suggests YouTube will feature audio ads sold by Google as well as other partners. It mentions the support of &#8220;new metrics&#8221; designed for audio-first creators and the ability to integrate YouTube data into industry-standard podcast measurement platforms. One page shows brands like Nielsen, Chartable and Podtrac listed as partners.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291669\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>The addition of a new &#8220;podcasts&#8221; vertical to YouTube would be a logical next step for the company.<\/p>\n<p>Over the years, YouTube has highlighted the service&#8217;s larger content categories by giving them their own homepages, as <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2015\/08\/25\/youtube-gaming-its-twitch-competitor-set-to-launch-tomorrow\/\">it did with YouTube Gaming<\/a> back in 2015 and with <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/09\/05\/youtube-launches-a-dedicated-fashion-vertical\/\">YouTube Fashion (now Fashion &amp; Beauty) in 2019<\/a>. Plus, YouTube content helps to power Google&#8217;s music streaming service, YouTube Music, which competes with other services like Spotify, where podcasts are a competitive advantage.<\/p>\n<p>Spotify has been looking to dominate the podcast advertising market and has made several acquisitions to bring related adtech in-house. As a result, Spotify has since been able to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/01\/10\/spotifys-increased-focus-on-podcasts-in-2019-includes-selling-its-own-ads\/\">sell its own ads<\/a>, introduce <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/08\/spotify-brings-streaming-ad-insertion-technology-to-podcasts\/\">streaming ad insertion technology<\/a>, launch <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/22\/spotify-to-launch-spotify-audience-network-an-audio-ad-marketplace\/\">its own audio ad marketplace<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/01\/06\/spotify-introduces-a-new-ad-format-for-podcasts-that-puts-clickable-cards-inside-shows\/\">is trying out new ad formats<\/a>. Meanwhile, as a video-centric platform, YouTube has been left out of much of this ad market growth.<\/p>\n<p>Podnews didn&#8217;t publish the full document and it&#8217;s not clear when the document was first produced or distributed, given references to launches that are listed as coming &#8220;in 2022&#8221; and the mention of Chartable, a company Spotify <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/16\/spotify-snaps-up-podcast-measurement-and-analytics-firms-podsights-and-chartable\/\">acquired<\/a> last month. YouTube didn&#8217;t comment to Podnews, per its article. We&#8217;ll update if a comment is provided to us.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>There were already several hints that YouTube was getting more serious about podcasts, after reports indicated the company hired a podcast executive, Kai Chuk, to lead its efforts in the space and had even begun offering cash to popular podcasters to film their shows. Now, a leaked document has unveiled more about YouTube&#8217;s plans in [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2003559,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"abeaa466-a005-3c3b-89f2-91b9a82f1315"},"categories":[449557068,329026,34923929],"tags":[576804406,81,1142,49818,2074982,272240,6567,1213469],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/06\/GettyImages-1149449084.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"Wordle chaos! Music","slug":"youtube-music","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1213469"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1213469"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1213469"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1213469"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1213469"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291319,"date":"2022-03-30T11:25:38","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T18:25:38","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291319"},"modified":"2022-03-31T01:20:12","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T08:20:12","slug":"why-nigeria-leads-the-way-in-ycs-participation-in-africa","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/why-nigeria-leads-the-way-in-ycs-participation-in-africa\/","title":{"rendered":"Why Nigeria leads the way in YC&#8217;s participation in Africa"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">It&#8217;s not a coincidence<\/span> that TechCrunch has covered more African startups in the last year than any period in our history. Many of those companies are Nigerian, and when we look at venture capital data, we can see why. The country had an incredible 2021 as the most active venture capital scene in Africa, collecting more than $1.8 billion, or 34% of the $5 billion raised across the continent, according to <a href=\"https:\/\/partechpartners.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Partech<\/a>, a pan-African VC firm that also tracks investments.<\/p>\n<p>The country has posted steady progress in the last three years as the leading African startup market. In 2019, startups based in Nigeria attracted $747 million, or 37% of Africa\u2019s total VC investment. Those numbers decreased to $307 million, or 21% of the continent&#8217;s total, the following year, though 2020 was a venture capital year much impacted by outside forces.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"w250oxm071\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/yc-w22-batch-nets-24-african-startups-including-18-from-nigeria\/\">YC W22 batch nets 24 African startups, including 18 from Nigeria<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;YC W22 batch nets 24 African startups, including 18 from Nigeria&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/yc-w22-batch-nets-24-african-startups-including-18-from-nigeria\/embed\/#?secret=e37pZ4OVdT#?secret=w250oxm071\" data-secret=\"w250oxm071\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Thanks in part to a global boom in venture capital activity last year, Nigeria became the first African country to singlehandedly cross the billion-dollar mark while also collecting bragging rights as the preferred destination for mega-investors like Tiger Global and SoftBank.<\/p>\n<h2>Y Combinator is paying attention<\/h2>\n<p>The ample optimism in Nigeria&#8217;s tech community and belief that better days are ahead are unsurprising, despite questions around investors\u2019 due diligence and the eyebrow-raising valuations of some of the nation&#8217;s startups.<\/p>\n<p>Speaking of valuations, no seed-stage company in the country is better priced than <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/yc-w22-batch-nets-24-african-startups-including-18-from-nigeria\/\">those in the Y Combinator club<\/a>. Yesterday, the accelerator graduated its first startup batch featuring its newly revamped terms. The new &#8220;standard deal&#8221; at YC now features more capital, and prices for Y Combinator graduates are reportedly greater than ever. (Keep in mind that only 10% of the current Y Combinator batch had monthly revenue of more than $50,000 when they were accepted into the program.)<\/p>\n<p>Apart from revenue thresholds, the accelerator shared another interesting statistic concerning Nigeria. With 18 startups, it is the first African country to have the third-largest representation when categorized by country. That&#8217;s a milestone for Nigeria, yes, but also an indication of how quickly the African startup scene has developed in a short period of time.<\/p>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Nigerian startups are a huge part of the current Y Combinator cohort. Looking at the data, that should not be a surprise.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574425,"featured_media":2290593,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"c8c6e769-ec40-3ede-8b72-f060865d94be"},"categories":[60523764,20429,17396],"tags":[2214,576849706,576845137,576848238,50092,427877930,96077,5426502,66822,449557042,38567,4510,66455,576998959],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[576796353,576796356],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/YC-DD-March-2022-general.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"All Analysis","slug":"market-analysis","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2291586,"date":"2022-03-30T10:58:28","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:58:28","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291586"},"modified":"2022-03-30T10:58:34","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:58:34","slug":"plastic-bag-bans","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/plastic-bag-bans\/","title":{"rendered":"Are plastic bag bans backfiring?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Plastic bags are bad. Ban them from supermarkets, and the problem is solved, right? Right? <em>Right?<\/em> Turns out, as is often the case, there may be a little bit more to that story. Researchers at the University of Georgia suggest that banning the sale of plastic bags may come with a side-dish of unintended consequences.<\/p>\n<p>The new analysis suggests that plastic bag ban policies &#8212; while well-intentioned &#8212; may end up having the opposite effect. The issue that comes up is that grocery bags are viewed as single-use items, but they often get a (brief) second lease on life as liners for small trash cans. Without the shopping bags available, people look for alternatives \u2014 which the researchers suggest means they buy small plastic garbage bags.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe know there is a demand for using plastic bags, and we know, if these policies go into effect, some bags will disappear or will become more costly to get,\u201d said Yu-Kai Huang, a postdoctoral researcher at the UGA Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources. \u201cSo, we wanted to see the effectiveness of this policy in reducing bag usage overall.\u201d<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291586\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Previous studies have looked at the effect of bag bans on plastic consumption, but not the combined effects of fees or a bag ban. An environmental economist, Huang used a new way to calculate the effect of either policy while also accounting for variables such as residents\u2019 income levels and an area\u2019s population density, both of which influence the amount of trash generated in a community.<\/p>\n<p>Keeping in mind the second life that plastic grocery bags take on in many homes, the team measured plastic trash bag sales in counties with bans or fees in place and compared them to other counties without such policies. The study found California communities with bag policies saw sales of four-gallon trash bags increase by 55%, to 75%, and sales of eight-gallon trash bags increase 87%, to 110%. These results echo earlier studies that also showed increases in sales of smaller plastic trash bags. While sales of smaller garbage bags jumped after policies were implemented, sales of larger 13-gallon trash bags \u2014 the size often found in kitchen trash cans in the U.S. \u2014 remained more or less unchanged.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Carryout grocery bags were substituted for similar sizes of trash bags before implementing the regulations,&#8221; the researchers wrote in the research paper. &#8220;After the regulations came into effect, consumers\u2019 plastic bag demand switched from regulated plastic bags to unregulated bags.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>If the average plastic bags drawer is anything to go by, most households use far more single-use bags than they have a need for trash bags, so it&#8217;s probably fair to say that taxing or banning single-use plastic bags is a net positive. But I found it interesting to remind us that even the best laid plans can have unintended consequences; a truth that appears to be as true in climate policy as it is elsewhere.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Plastic bags are bad. Ban them from supermarkets, and the problem is solved, right? Right? Right? Turns out, as is often the case, there may be a little bit more to that story. Researchers at the University of Georgia suggest that banning the sale of plastic bags may come with a side-dish of unintended consequences. bag ban","slug":"plastic-bag-ban","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/2575735"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=2575735"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=2575735"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=2575735"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=2575735"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":42976,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/recycling\/","name":"recycling","slug":"recycling","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/42976"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=42976"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=42976"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=42976"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=42976"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291484,"date":"2022-03-30T10:51:57","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:51:57","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291484"},"modified":"2022-03-30T10:52:11","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:52:11","slug":"quantum-machines-acquires-qdevil-to-build-out-its-full-stack-quantum-orchestration-platform","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/quantum-machines-acquires-qdevil-to-build-out-its-full-stack-quantum-orchestration-platform\/","title":{"rendered":"Quantum Machines acquires QDevil to build out its full-stack quantum orchestration platform"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.quantum-machines.co\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Quantum Machines<\/a>, the well-funded Israeli startup that specializes in building control systems for quantum computers, today <a href=\"https:\/\/www.quantum-machines.co\/blog\/quantum-machines-acquires-qdevil\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> that it has acquired <a href=\"https:\/\/qdevil.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">QDevil<\/a>, a well-known Danish company that specializes in building control hardware for quantum systems. The two companies did not disclose the financial details of the transaction and, according to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/organization\/qdevil\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Crunchbase<\/a>, the company only raised about \u20ac1 million, mostly in the form of grants. But it has become a significant player in the market and counts many of the established quantum computing research institutes and commercial entities as its customers.<\/p>\n<p>Quantum Machines founder and CEO Itamar Sivan told me he first met the QDevil team in person at the last in-person <a href=\"https:\/\/www.aps.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">APS<\/a> March meeting back in 2019 and the companies continued to talk over the course of the next few years. &#8220;At some point, we realized that it would be highly impactful to join forces, because their products are actually complementary to ours. And therefore, we can now provide a more comprehensive orchestration platform,&#8221; said Sivan. It&#8217;s one thing to build a quantum processing unit, after all (or <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/08\/quantware-will-build-you-a-custom-25-qubit-quantum-processor-in-30-days\/\">buy one off the shelf<\/a>), but it takes a lot of expertise to then turn that into a complete quantum computer.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291529\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291529\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291529\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"576\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png 3333w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/QM-and-Qdevil12.png?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291529\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Quantum Machines<\/p><\/div><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291484\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>One of QDevil&#8217;s main products is its <a href=\"https:\/\/qdevil.com\/qdac\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">QDAC<\/a>, a &#8220;high-precision low-noise computer-controlled voltage generator,&#8221; as the company describes it. Qubits obviously hate nothing more than noise, so QDevil&#8217;s low-noise DAC makes it easier for operators to control their qubits. In addition, QDevil also offers a range of other electronics and specialized components for operating quantum processors. Combined with Quantum Machines&#8217; Pulse Processing Units and software, this will allow the two companies to offer a full-stack solution for orchestrating quantum computers. Sivan also stressed that QDevil has done quite a bit of work on controlling quantum dots, which are an increasingly hot topic in the quantum computing world.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;QDevil is one of the premier providers of electronics for quantum computing,&#8221; said Dr.\u00a0<span class=\"xn-person\">Jonatan Kutchinsky<\/span>, CEO of QDevil. &#8220;We&#8217;re delighted to join up with Quantum Machines, a company whose mission and goals align so perfectly with our own. Together we will continue to further develop the quantum community in\u00a0<span class=\"xn-location\">Denmark<\/span>\u00a0and deliver revolutionary technologies that will make it seamless for companies developing quantum computers to realize the potential of their QPUs.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Sivan also noted that this acquisition brings a lot of new talent to Quantum Machines &#8212; and there is only a finite number of PhD physicists with a specialization in quantum mechanics on the market.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It&#8217;s an amazing acquisition for us because it&#8217;s both the technology, the products, the customer base and the people,&#8221; Sivan said. &#8220;It&#8217;s really all of that. They have accomplished amazing achievements and I can firmly say now that [Quantum Machines] plus QDevil is selling to almost all the players in quantum computing globally &#8212; above 90% &#8212; including corporates, startups, national labs.&#8221;<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Chances are, this isn&#8217;t Quantum Machines&#8217; last acquisition. The company has now raised <a href=\"https:\/\/www.prnewswire.com\/news-releases\/quantum-machines-raises-50m-to-make-quantum-computers-ubiquitous-and-disruptive-across-all-industries-301369668.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$73 million<\/a>, so it has a bit of a war chest to acquire smaller companies and build out its platform. We&#8217;ll likely see the same play out across the market, given how many small, highly specialized companies there are right now, with a number of larger players trying to build full-stack platforms.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;I believe that yes, acquisitions are definitely going to be a strategy for Quantum Machines and, I believe, for other companies as well,&#8221; Sivan said. &#8220;Because as the value chain forms, I believe that you will see that eventually, there will be layers in the value chain that will be more or less significant.&#8221;<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Quantum Machines, the well-funded Israeli startup that specializes in building control systems for quantum computers, today announced that it has acquired QDevil, a well-known Danish company that specializes in building control hardware for quantum systems. The two companies did not disclose the financial details of the transaction and, according to Crunchbase, the company only raised ":96,"filesize":2230947,"mime_type":"image\/png","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/PPU-chip.png?w=96&h=96&crop=1"},"guest-author-128":{"file":"PPU-chip.png?resize=128,128","width":128,"height":128,"filesize":2230947,"mime_type":"image\/png","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/PPU-chip.png?w=128&h=128&crop=1"},"concierge-thumb":{"file":"PPU-chip.png?resize=50,25","width":50,"height":25,"filesize":2230947,"mime_type":"image\/png","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/PPU-chip.png?w=50"},"full":{"file":"PPU-chip.png","width":1024,"height":512,"mime_type":"image\/png","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/PPU-chip.png"}},"image_meta":{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0","keywords":[]},"filesize":2230947},"source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/PPU-chip.png","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/2291530"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/attachment"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2291530"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/34511731"}]}}],"wp:term":[[{"id":60523764,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/fundings-exits\/","name":"Fundings Exits","slug":"fundings-exits","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/60523764"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=60523764"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=60523764"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=60523764"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449560964,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/ma\/","name":"M&amp;A","slug":"ma","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/449560964"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=449560964"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=449560964"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=449560964"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":446313605,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/science\/","name":"Science","slug":"science","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/446313605"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcr dots","slug":"quantum-dots","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1071670"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1071670"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1071670"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1071670"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1071670"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576617139,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/quantum-machines\/","name":"Quantum Machines","slug":"quantum-machines","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576617139"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576617139"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576617139"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576617139"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576617139"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":11979,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/quantum-mechanics\/","name":"Quantum Mechanics","slug":"quantum-mechanics","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/11979"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=11979"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=11979"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=11979"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=11979"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291053,"date":"2022-03-30T10:22:54","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:22:54","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291053"},"modified":"2022-03-30T12:55:11","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T19:55:11","slug":"flux-marine-revs-up-its-electric-outboard-business-with-15m-a-round","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/flux-marine-revs-up-its-electric-outboard-business-with-15m-a-round\/","title":{"rendered":"Flux Marine revs up its electric outboard business with $15M A round"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The race is certainly on in the electrification of boating \u2026 even if everyone is jockeying for position before the market materializes. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.fluxmarine.com\">Flux Marine<\/a> is joining the likes of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/22\/pure-watercraft-ramps-up-its-electric-outboard-motors-with-a-23m-series-a\/\">Pure<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/11\/zin-boats-reinvents-the-electric-speedboat-in-a-bid-to-become-the-tesla-of-the-sea\/\">Zin<\/a> in trying to convert some of our waterways&#8217; gas-guzzling outboards to cleaner, quieter battery powered ones, and the company just raised $15.5 million ahead of a planned summer shipping date.<\/p>\n<p>The conversion of the boating world to electrics is progressing slowly for lots of reasons, but it also seems as inevitable as the electrification of land vehicles. Boats are such big investments, and used so differently from cars, and physically are so much more power-hungry, that it&#8217;s not quite as simple to make the switch.<\/p>\n<p>Flux has designed for, it claims, both convenience and efficiency, with a new take on the traditional rear-mounted outboard.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291053\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;We\u2019ve taken a ground-up design approach that places the electric motor above the waterline for scalability, but does not use any legacy combustion outboard parts,&#8221; CEO Ben Sorkin told TechCrunch. &#8220;Our lower unit was developed in-house to accommodate a belt drive, incorporate a closed-loop cooling system with active feedback, and reduce hydrodynamic drag.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;When looking at electric motors (electric machines), they are generally rated for a peak torque, determined by geometry and magnetics, and a continuous torque, which is determined by thermal management. Because a boat is subject to high drag forces from water, the key is in designing power electronics and a thermal management system to get the continuous torque as close as possible to peak torque,&#8221; Sorkin continued. &#8220;The end result is a lighter, more efficient total propulsion solution.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291574\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291574\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291574\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg\" alt=\"A man drives a dinghy with an electric motor on the back.\" width=\"1024\" height=\"666\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg 2000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg?resize=150,98 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg?resize=300,195 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg?resize=768,500 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg?resize=680,442 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg?resize=1536,999 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-1.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291574\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Flux Marine<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>They also design the battery packs, which is of course a double-edged sword: They&#8217;ll be good&#8230; but expensive, and you can&#8217;t just go out and grab a car battery to add another few miles to the range. (Actual range depends so much on the hull, weight and speed that it&#8217;s impossible to predict, but figure somewhere in the 40-70 mile range.)<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The benefits of electric conversion in general are obvious enough that they scarcely need recounting: cleaner, quieter, greener, easier to maintain and potentially better performance.<\/p>\n<p>The downside is primarily cost: Flux aims to make its motors available for $4,000-$12,000, depending on whether you want a 15-horsepower equivalent (one person in a dinghy), 40 HP (a few people in an aluminum rowboat) or 70 HP (a few people in an aluminum rowboat, but going faster); a 100 HP equivalent one is planned as well. The battery pack is sold separately for $3,500 at the 15 HP level, up to $40K for the 70 HP one if you want to go more than a couple miles.<\/p>\n<p>Obviously that limits the number of people who can afford to go green, but boating is kind of an expensive hobby to begin with. If you want to get on the water for two bills, get a paddleboard \u2014 a hull and motor will run you a couple thousand bucks unless you buy the algae-encrusted one from that guy down the dock.<\/p>\n<p>Preorders were opened last year and Sorkin said the company is on track to deliver its first motors this summer, hopefully in time for boating season. Lead times should decrease as they scale up over the next year, he added. In-person demos will be available in Rhode Island (where the company is based and just got a fat tax credit) and Connecticut.<\/p>\n<p>The $15.5 million A round was led by Ocean Zero, with participation from Boost VC, Winklevoss Capital and previous early investors.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The race is certainly on in the electrification of boating \u2026 even if everyone is jockeying for position before the market materializes. Flux Marine is joining the likes of Pure and Zin in trying to convert some of our waterways&#8217; gas-guzzling outboards to cleaner, quieter battery powered ones, and the company just raised $15.5 million [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":12084691,"featured_media":2291573,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"b27b3c15-7fa1-3917-a125-8a0dbc145b33"},"categories":[576602978,60523764,449557086,1102388,449223024,576602979,20429],"tags":[57927,576794373,449557042],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/flux-marine-2.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"Behold ttps:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=57927"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=57927"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=57927"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=57927"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576794373,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/electric-boats\/","name":"electric boats","slug":"electric-boats","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576794373"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576794373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576794373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576794373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576794373"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291537,"date":"2022-03-30T09:58:17","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:58:17","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291537"},"modified":"2022-03-30T11:21:29","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T18:21:29","slug":"google-adds-limited-markdown-support-to-google-docs","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/google-adds-limited-markdown-support-to-google-docs\/","title":{"rendered":"Google adds limited Markdown support to Google Docs"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Google shared <a href=\"http:\/\/workspaceupdates.googleblog.com\/2022\/03\/compose-with-markdown-in-google-docs-on.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a blog post<\/a> with Google Workspace customers announcing some good news for all <a href=\"https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Markdown\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Markdown<\/a> fans out there. Google Docs can now automatically convert Markdown formatting to rich text.<\/p>\n<p>If you\u2019re not familiar with Markdown, this markup language has become very popular over the past few years if you want to write structured documents \u2014 and especially web content. For instance, popular note-taking tools like <a href=\"https:\/\/www.notion.so\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Notion<\/a> or <a href=\"https:\/\/bear.app\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bear<\/a> support Markdown. Content management systems like WordPress also let you <a href=\"https:\/\/wordpress.com\/support\/wordpress-editor\/blocks\/markdown-block\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">enable Markdown<\/a> as a way to write new posts.<\/p>\n<p>This new feature for Google Docs is off by default. You have to manually turn it on in the settings first. That\u2019s why I\u2019m writing this post. If you want to enable Markdown support, open a document in Google Docs, head over to the top of the screen, go to &#8220;Tools&#8221; then &#8220;Preferences&#8221; and enable &#8220;Automatically detect Markdown.&#8221; After that, you\u2019re good to go. If you can&#8217;t see the feature today, that&#8217;s normal, as the company is rolling out the new feature progressively over the coming days.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291537\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Again, don\u2019t expect extensive Markdown support. Google Docs is still a rich text editor and this isn\u2019t going to magically change once you enable the Markdown feature.<\/p>\n<p>Instead, Google Docs will replace common Markdown formatting with rich text. For instance, you can create links with parentheses and brackets like <code>[this](https:\/\/techcrunch.com)<\/code>. You can italicize text by surrounding it with the <code>*<\/code> character.<\/p>\n<p>Google Docs supports different levels of headings, bold, italic, strikethrough and links. Numbered lists and unstructured lists still get automatically formatted like before.<\/p>\n<p>In other words, this new feature complements some keyboard shortcuts. It also makes it easier to copy Markdown content from one app to Google Docs, which can be particularly useful if you use a Markdown editor like <a href=\"https:\/\/ulysses.app\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Ulysses<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>But\u2026 that doesn\u2019t work the other way. What\u2019s great about Markdown is that it\u2019s a plain text format that is compatible with multiple apps and services.<\/p>\n<p>For instance, Google Docs should let you natively export the current document as Markdown so that you can quickly copy and paste it anywhere Markdown is supported. I know, there is a plugin for that. But not all companies are comfortable with plugins.<\/p>\n<p>Hey Google, it\u2019s a nice first step, but you have to iterate and offer more Markdown features, please.<\/p>\n<p><img loading=\"lazy\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-2291545\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg?w=660\" alt=\"\" width=\"660\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg 1118w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg?resize=146,150 146w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg?resize=291,300 291w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg?resize=768,791 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg?resize=660,680 660w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Screen-Shot-2022-03-30-at-6.51.04-PM.jpeg?resize=32,32 32w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 660px) 100vw, 660px\" \/><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Google shared a blog post with Google Workspace customers announcing some good news for all Markdown fans out there. Google Docs can now automatically convert Markdown formatting to rich text. If you\u2019re not familiar with Markdown, this markup language has become very popular over the past few years if you want to write structured documents om\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=446419805"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=446419805"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=446419805"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=446419805"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2289744,"date":"2022-03-30T09:58:04","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:58:04","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2289744"},"modified":"2022-03-30T11:42:49","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T18:42:49","slug":"selected-ai-startups-from-ycs-winter-22-batch","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/selected-ai-startups-from-ycs-winter-22-batch\/","title":{"rendered":"Selected AI startups from YC&#8217;s Winter &#8217;22 batch"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Dozens of startups in Y Combinator&#8217;s Winter 2022 cohort do something that could be described as artificial intelligence. Though the term has lost much of its meaning, it&#8217;s still an important part of the tech landscape, and both using it and enabling it are fertile ground for new companies. Here are 14 notable startups from the latest batch.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.eventualcomputing.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Eventual<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2022 in San Francisco, CA<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2289744\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Jay Chia, Sammy Sidhu<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> A turnkey data warehouse for images and video. Eventual ingests, organizes and processes imaging data all on one platform. Also handles queries, simple integration with cloud providers and smart scheduling to save costs on compute.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;Currently users jerry-rig one together with multiple vendors or hard to manage open-source frameworks. We are a one-stop shop.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> Many companies require some kind of image analysis pipeline and making a one-stop shop is a valid approach to the market. Keeping customers that start to scale and squint at the costs could be a challenge, though.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/whitelabgx.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Whitelab Genomics<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2019 in Paris, France<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Julien Cottineau, David Delbourgo<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> An AI-powered platform for discovery and design of genomic therapies. Data science and databasing for &#8220;scientific, technical, biological, genomic, and experimental&#8221; data sets. Plus suggestions for experimental design and workflows.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;We help our customers develop more genomic medicines, faster, in leaner ways and make those revolutionary drugs more accessible to patients in need.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> AI drug discovery is hot, but few have created serious value. Still, it&#8217;s obviously promising and specializing in genomic therapy is a good idea. How they&#8217;ll do the woollier workflow and design stuff I don&#8217;t know.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.aisupervision.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">AiSupervision<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in Mannheim, Germany<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Alex Conway, Sascha Lang<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> An OS for production lines that records, digitizes and monitors factories with lots of workers. Includes real-time alerts, automated reports and photo-based quality control.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291504\" style=\"width: 751px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291504\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291504\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/aisupervision.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"741\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/aisupervision.png 741w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/aisupervision.png?resize=150,77 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/aisupervision.png?resize=300,154 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/aisupervision.png?resize=680,350 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/aisupervision.png?resize=50,26 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 741px) 100vw, 741px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291504\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> AiSupervision<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;We automate what the best supervisors would do if they watched everything that\u2019s happening inside your factory.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> If it&#8217;s anything like what Amazon is already doing, it&#8217;s a short ride to hell for the workers. But if they can make this humane and helpful, many factories would consider it as a way to integrate multiple tracking tools.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291503\" style=\"width: 279px\" class=\"wp-caption alignright\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291503\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2291503 size-medium\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/powerhouse.jpg?w=269\" alt=\"\" width=\"269\" height=\"300\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/powerhouse.jpg 500w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/powerhouse.jpg?resize=134,150 134w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/powerhouse.jpg?resize=269,300 269w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/powerhouse.jpg?resize=45,50 45w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 269px) 100vw, 269px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291503\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Powerhouse AI<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.pwh.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Powerhouse AI<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in Singapore<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Kushal Pillay and Ivo Verhaegh<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> An automated inventory solution for warehouses. Lots of worker hours are used up doing this thankless task, so why not automate it? Powerhouse uses ordinary phones that count inventory using regular pictures taken by staff. It&#8217;s part of a broader effort to make warehouses smarter and more efficient.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;They just take a picture with their phone, and our software counts the boxes.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> I thought I heard the presenter say 97% accuracy, but the site says 99%. I don&#8217;t do inventory these days but hopefully it can be trusted enough that it doesn&#8217;t require hand recounting.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/strongcompute.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Strong Compute<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in Sydney, Australia<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Ben Sand<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> An ML training platform that focuses on ultra-high-performance and efficiency. By performing optimizations &#8220;around&#8221; a model (like pre-computing values, identifying bottlenecks and so on) they claim to be able to improve training times by orders of magnitude.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;The future of Cloud Computing, priced by performance not consumption.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/09\/strong-compute-wants-speed-up-your-ml-model-training\/\">Frederic looked into it a few weeks ago<\/a>, and it seems like a nice upscale competitor that plays nicely with existing solutions.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.realitydefender.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Reality Defender<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in New York<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Gaurav Bharaj, Benjamin Colman and Ali Shahriyari<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> An easy to use tool with which companies can scan media for deepfake content. Produces alerts, report cards and other ways to visualize and take action against fake content.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;Empower humanity to recognize the truth.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> This will almost certainly be an arms race, but a tool for catching the low-hanging fruit will be wanted to prevent oceans of fake profiles, lightly disguised spam content and so on. Their methods may take ongoing refining though, which may not be cheap or easy.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.korrai.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">KorrAI<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2020 in Canada<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Rahul Anand and Rob McEwan<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> A geospatial and satellite data platform for mining operations that pulls together multiple sources and offers a more efficient way to locate and organize mineral collection. Early cases have reduced lead times from a year to a few weeks.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;We&#8217;ll change mining more in the next five years than it has in the last 50.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> We&#8217;ve seen a lot of movement in the mining area recently, probably a sign that this legacy industry is investing its considerable resources in modernization. It&#8217;s a promising space to get into right now.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/mutable.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mutable AI<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in Pittsburgh<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Omar Shams<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> A machine learning-powered polishing engine for Python code and Jupyter notebooks. These notebooks are often cobbled together as experiments with no plan for being production code \u2014 but then one gets adopted as a popular tool and needs to be cleaned up. Mutable AI does this automatically, autocompleting, refactoring and minimizing quickly and easily.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291506\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291506\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2291506 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"283\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png 1600w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png?resize=150,41 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png?resize=300,83 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png?resize=768,212 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png?resize=680,188 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png?resize=1536,424 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/mutableai.png?resize=50,14 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291506\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Before (left) and after.<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;Be kind to your teammates and future self.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> Would it be useful? Probably&#8230; I&#8217;ve had to use hacked-together notebooks and wouldn&#8217;t want to do it full time. Is there a big market for it? Hard to say. The company seems born out of the founder&#8217;s own frustrations at the frontier of ML research, so maybe there are others like him looking for this.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/voize.de\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Voize<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2020 in Berlin, Germany<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Fabio and Marcel Schmidberger, Erik Ziegler<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> Voice-powered filling out of forms for healthcare workers. These folks spend hours doing paperwork, and it&#8217;s a sea of fields that need to be tabbed through and typed in. Voize lets them speak directly into a smartphone and it creates structured records from that.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;The digital voice assistant for non-desk workers.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> Speaking medical information out loud while walking around seems like a big no-no&#8230; I have a feeling there&#8217;s a reason it&#8217;s done the way it&#8217;s done. But streamlining medical recordkeeping is something that definitely needs to happen.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/mintlify.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mintlify<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in San Francisco<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Hahnbee Lee and Han Wang<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> An automatic code documentation engine that reads your code and safely inserts comments that put it in context. Coders don&#8217;t always have time to do that and it makes code auditing and reuse difficult \u2014 so having a tool that does it for them (at least to a basic degree) could save time and effort.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;Everyone suffers from documentation debt.&#8221; Also, regarding co-founder Han Wang, &#8220;Knows over 100 cow jokes.&#8221; We&#8217;ll see about that.<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> The proof is in the pudding for this one, but I bet a ton of companies would love to be able to say every line of code is explained. &#8220;Mintlify it before you send it to me next time!&#8221;<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.speechly.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Speechly<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2016 in Helsinki, Finland<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Hannes Heikinheimo and Otto Soderlund<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> On-device speech recognition for apps that don&#8217;t want to have to call a cloud service. Doing any process locally is preferable, but until recently there was too much trade-off on the accuracy versus speed side. If Speechly can make quick and accurate speech recognition that easily fills in forms or summons relevant information, that&#8217;s one less online API call to make.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;Reduce cloud costs, enhance privacy and ensure zero-latency experiences by running Speechly directly on the end-users\u2019 device.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> Others are definitely pursuing this (including monsters like Google and Amazon), but having an independent and functional solution could be very valuable for app creators who want to keep their code as local as possible.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/dynamofl.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">DynamoFL<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in San Francisco<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Christian Lau and Vaikkunth Mugunthan<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> A plug and play federated learning platform for AI models in privacy-critical industries. Federated learning is an established technique and has already generated a lot of value, but it&#8217;s not the easiest thing to deploy. DynamoFL slips into training workflows that use private data and makes or keeps them private.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;In three minutes, we can plug our federated learning module into your existing ML workflow.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> If it were easier to use federated learning, more niche industries in healthcare, finance and so on would probably be likely to deploy ML models. Whether they can keep the general ease of use that other ML tools have cultivated is a question mark.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/starlingmedical.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Starling<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2019 in Houston, TX<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Alex Arevalos, Drew Hendricks and Hannah McKenney<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> AI-powered home urinalysis using an in-bathroom spectrometer. Using a usually lab-bound device for identifying and detecting substances, Starling aims to catch things like bladder infections and other problems early, or do home monitoring that would normally involve bringing a urine sample in.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291514\" style=\"width: 510px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291514\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291514\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/starling.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"363\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291514\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Starling<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;What information did you just flush down the toilet?&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> Depending on how easy it is to use, this could be a new standard tool for a lot of medical preventive stuff. I can see it being everywhere in two years.<\/p>\n<hr \/>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/sievedata.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sieve Data<\/a><\/p>\n<p><strong>Founded: <\/strong>2021 in Berkeley, CA<\/p>\n<p><strong>By:<\/strong> Abhinav Ayalur and Mokshith Voodarla<\/p>\n<p><strong>Building:<\/strong> A dead simple video analysis platform that scans incoming video for things like people, objects and situations and returns that metadata quickly. Powers search, storage, moderation &#8212; anything you need to understand video to do.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Quote:<\/strong> &#8220;You never have to train a model or manage a data set. Just push video and get results.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>TC Quick Take<\/strong>\u2122<strong>:<\/strong> I just wrote up a company called <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/16\/twelve-labs-makes-searching-inside-videos-simple-and-powerful-propelled-by-5m-seed-round\/\">Twelve Labs<\/a> that does something like this and it seems like a very promising niche. It&#8217;s hard to pick winners at this stage, it will depend a lot on emerging video use cases.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/yc-demo-day-winter-2022\/\"><img src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/YC-DD-2022-banner.jpg\" alt=\"Read more about YC Demo Day on TechCrunch\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Dozens of startups in Y Combinator&#8217;s Winter 2022 cohort do something that could be described as artificial intelligence. Though the term has lost much of its meaning, it&#8217;s still an important part of the tech landscape, and both using it and enabling it are fertile ground for new companies. Here are 14 notable startups from Day","slug":"yc-demo-day","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/41385386"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=41385386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=41385386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=41385386"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=41385386"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576998959,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/yc-demo-day-winter-2022\/","name":"YC
