2022","slug":"yc-demo-day-winter-2022","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576998959"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576998959"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576998959"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576998959"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576998959"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291467,"date":"2022-03-30T09:55:09","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:55:09","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291467"},"modified":"2022-03-30T10:42:14","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:42:14","slug":"twitters-professional-accounts-profile-setting-available-worldwide","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/twitters-professional-accounts-profile-setting-available-worldwide\/","title":{"rendered":"Twitter&#8217;s &#8216;Professional Accounts&#8217; profile setting is now available to all users"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Twitter has <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterBusiness\/status\/1508855707684438016\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> that it&#8217;s expanding access to its &#8220;Professional Accounts&#8221; profile setting to all users globally. Up until now, users have had to apply to convert their account into a professional one. Now, everyone on the platform can opt into a professional account directly from their account settings.<\/p>\n<p>A professional account, which Twitter refers to as &#8220;Twitter for Professionals,&#8221; gives brands and creators access to additional\u00a0tools to distinguish their profile, quickly promote content through ads and capitalize on Twitter\u2019s future\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/28\/twitter-launches-u-s-e-commerce-pilot-that-lets-users-shop-from-profiles\/\">e-commerce efforts<\/a>, including its \u201cShop Module\u201d that offers brands, businesses and other retailers the ability to showcase their products to Twitter users directly on the business\u2019 profile.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">\ud83c\udf0e Now globally available for everyone, Professional Accounts are a new tool on Twitter that allows you to have a unique and clearly defined presence on the platform.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291467\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>&mdash; Twitter Business (@TwitterBusiness) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/TwitterBusiness\/status\/1508855707684438016?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">March 29, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Users can find a Twitter for Professionals tab by swiping open the sidebar from the Home timeline on the app. A \u201cSwitch to Professional\u201d tab will also appear under profile settings.<\/p>\n<p>Once you select the professional account setting, you&#8217;re asked to pick a category to display on your profile that best describes your account, such as automotive, apparel\/clothing, advertising\/marketing and beauty. Twitter will then ask you to select an account type. There are two options: business or creator. Twitter notes that the business account is best suited for brands, retail shops, service providers and organizations, whereas the creator account is aimed toward public figures, artists and influencers. You also can toggle between the two account settings if you change your mind.<\/p>\n<p>Once you\u2019ve converted to a professional account, you will be prompted to follow topics, promote a tweet in an ad campaign or customize your profile with modules that your account qualifies for. These include an about module, a shop module and a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/19\/twitter-is-testing-a-feature-that-puts-users-revue-newsletters-on-their-profiles\/\">newsletter module<\/a>\u00a0for users on Revue, the newsletter service Twitter\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/26\/twitter-acquires-revue\/\">acquired<\/a> last year.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>If you decide that you no longer want a professional account, you can switch back to a personal one by going into your settings and navigating to the &#8220;Edit Professional Profile&#8221; option and selecting &#8220;Switch Account Type.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Twitter classifies anyone who uses Twitter for work as a professional. To qualify for a professional account, users must have no repeated history of violating guidelines, and they must be authentic, with an account name, bio and profile picture. Parody and fan accounts are not eligible for professional accounts.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"cApvd5ZmxV\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/10\/01\/twitter-for-professionals-will-begin-to-roll-out-this-week-for-businesses-and-creators\/\">Twitter for Professionals will begin to roll out this week for businesses and creators<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Twitter for Professionals will begin to roll out this week for businesses and creators&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/10\/01\/twitter-for-professionals-will-begin-to-roll-out-this-week-for-businesses-and-creators\/embed\/#?secret=63m7zvCg1o#?secret=cApvd5ZmxV\" data-secret=\"cApvd5ZmxV\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Twitter has announced that it&#8217;s expanding access to its &#8220;Professional Accounts&#8221; profile setting to all users globally. Up until now, users have had to apply to convert their account into a professional one. Now, everyone on the platform can opt into a professional account directly from their account settings. A professional account, which Twitter refers es?tags=449557101"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557101"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557101"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":1404273,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/social-20\/","name":"social","slug":"social-20","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1404273"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1404273"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=1404273"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1404273"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1404273"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":49818,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/social-media\/","name":"social media","slug":"social-media","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/49818"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=49818"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=49818"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576944111,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/social-media-apps\/","name":"social media apps","slug":"social-media-apps","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576944111"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576944111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576944111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576944111"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576944111"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":599182,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/twitter\/","name":"Twitter","slug":"twitter","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/599182"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=599182"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291477,"date":"2022-03-30T09:51:37","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:51:37","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291477"},"modified":"2022-03-30T13:38:56","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T20:38:56","slug":"tiktok-snapchat-parental-controls-attorneys-general","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/tiktok-snapchat-parental-controls-attorneys-general\/","title":{"rendered":"State attorneys want TikTok and Snap to support third-party parental control apps"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">TikTok and Snapchat need more parental controls, a <a href=\"https:\/\/1li23g1as25g1r8so11ozniw-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/NAAG-Final-Letter-Parental-Control-App.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">letter<\/a> signed by 44 attorneys general stated.<\/p>\n<p>Yesterday, the National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG) sent a series of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.naag.org\/policy-letter\/naag-urges-tiktok-and-snapchat-to-give-parents-more-control\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">concerns<\/a> to the two social apps, which are commonly used among teens.<\/p>\n<p>The attorneys general cited a range of problems they had with the social media apps, including, more broadly, the negative impact they can have on the physical, emotional and mental well-being of children and teens. They also noted that content depicting abusive sexual relationships can seriously harm a child&#8217;s view of a healthy relationship, helping to perpetuate domestic abuse and human trafficking. And the letter stressed that TikTok and Snapchat don&#8217;t effectively collaborate with third-party parental control apps to allow parents to monitor and restrict what their children can do on their platforms.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291477\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>The NAAG cited a study from one such app, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bark.us\/annual-report-2021\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bark<\/a>, which analyzed 3.4 billion messages in 2021 across 30 apps to find that 74.6% of teens were involved in a self-harm\/suicidal situation, 90.73% encountered nudity or sexual content online and 93.31% engaged in conversations about drugs or alcohol.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cParental control apps can alert parents or schools to messages and posts on your platforms that have the potential to be harmful and dangerous. Apps can also alert parents if their child manifests a desire for self-harm or suicide,\u201d the letter reads.<\/p>\n<p>Snapchat already has some in-app <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/16\/instagram-rolls-out-new-safety-tools-for-parents\/\">parental controls<\/a>, as does <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/11\/17\/tiktok-expands-parental-controls-to-include-search-commenting-and-account-privacy\/\">TikTok<\/a>, but this group of attorneys general wants the platforms to be more compatible with third-party parental control apps, though they didn\u2019t endorse a particular product. They suggested that parental control apps could access social media app features like private messaging, which the built-in parental controls don&#8217;t monitor. Plus, third-party apps could better filter the user-generated content that appears in the apps&#8217; main feeds.<\/p>\n<p>Still, third-party control apps introduce their own swath of problems regarding which tactics they use to surveil children.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Though TikTok and Snapchat did already have parental controls, its competitor Instagram did not. After a series of Senate hearings about the impact of social media on teen mental health, Meta recently began rolling out <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/16\/instagram-rolls-out-new-safety-tools-for-parents\/\">parental controls<\/a> on Instagram, a long-overdue safety measure.<\/p>\n<p>But teen safety on these platforms remains a concern in the U.S. government, regardless of whether or not parental controls are in place. President Biden even mentioned the threat of social media to teen mental health in his <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/01\/biden-social-media-mental-health-state-of-the-union\/\">State of the Union address<\/a>, which former Facebook employee and whistleblower Frances Haugen attended as an honored guest.<\/p>\n<p>TikTok is more popular among teens than Instagram, which has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/11\/instagram-bonuses-reels-tiktok\/\">poured money<\/a> into its TikTok clone Reels to keep up. But as TikTok holds its ground as the fastest-growing social app, Meta has gone to even more dramatic lengths to maintain its prominence. The Washington Post <a href=\"https:\/\/www.washingtonpost.com\/technology\/2022\/03\/30\/facebook-tiktok-targeted-victory\/?request-id=223d214e-1ead-4b0f-80b5-3586e0ed866c&amp;pml=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported today<\/a> that Meta hired Targeted Victory, a Republican consulting firm, to turn the public against TikTok. In some cases, Targeted Victory attempted to influence public opinion by claiming that certain dangerous viral trends began on TikTok, though they actually <a href=\"https:\/\/www.insider.com\/slap-a-teacher-challenge-tiktok-october-trend-2021-10\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">started on Facebook<\/a>. TechCrunch also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/11\/30\/facebook-targeted-victory-definers-gop\/\">reported<\/a> in 2018 that Facebook had worked with Targeted Victory to help slow progress on legislation that would impact the platform\u2019s political ad spending.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cTargeted Victory\u2019s corporate practice manages bipartisan teams on behalf of our clients. It is public knowledge we have worked with Meta for several years and we are proud of the work we have done,&#8221; the firm&#8217;s CEO Zac Moffatt said in a statement.<\/p>\n<p>In any case, there&#8217;s only so much that parental controls can do to keep apps safe for teens &#8212; it&#8217;s on the apps themselves too to make sure that they aren&#8217;t serving teens unsafe content.<\/p>\n<p><em>Update, 3\/30\/22 at 4:38 PM EST with statement from Targeted Victory.<\/em><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"3nLetIxmE5\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/11\/30\/facebook-targeted-victory-definers-gop\/\">Facebook quietly hired Republican strategy firm Targeted Victory<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Facebook quietly hired Republican strategy firm Targeted Victory&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/11\/30\/facebook-targeted-victory-definers-gop\/embed\/#?secret=MtwdorjDEB#?secret=3nLetIxmE5\" data-secret=\"3nLetIxmE5\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"AOVwHEQr7K\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/01\/biden-social-media-mental-health-state-of-the-union\/\">Biden will address social media&#8217;s mental health impact at State of the Union<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Biden will address social media&#8217;s mental health impact at State of the Union&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/01\/biden-social-media-mental-health-state-of-the-union\/embed\/#?secret=yT8olHrs8u#?secret=AOVwHEQr7K\" data-secret=\"AOVwHEQr7K\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>TikTok and Snapchat need more parental controls, a letter signed by 44 attorneys general stated. Yesterday, the National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG) sent a series of concerns to the two social apps, which are commonly used among teens. The attorneys general cited a range of problems they had with the social media apps, including, culture","slug":"internet-culture","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/76373"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=76373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=76373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=76373"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=76373"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":76517,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/mobile-applications\/","name":"mobile applications","slug":"mobile-applications","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/76517"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=76517"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=76517"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=76517"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=76517"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":973655,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/parental-controls\/","name":"parental controls","slug":"parental-controls","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/973655"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=973655"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=973655"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=973655"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=973655"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":7054,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/senate\/","name":"senate","slug":"senate","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/7054"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=7054"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=7054"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=7054"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=7054"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":80687524,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/snapchat\/","name":"Snapchat","slug":"snapchat","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/80687524"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=80687524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=80687524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=80687524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=80687524"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291279,"date":"2022-03-30T09:11:03","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:11:03","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291279"},"modified":"2022-03-30T10:26:17","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:26:17","slug":"eu-expands-ecodesign-rules","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/eu-expands-ecodesign-rules\/","title":{"rendered":"Europe lays out expanded ecodesign rules with plan for digital product passports"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The European Union has announced a new bundle of sustainability-focused policy proposals that will expand existing ecodesign rules on energy efficiency by encouraging longer product lifespans, supporting the growth of circular economy business models and helping consumers combat greenwashing and make more environmentally friendly purchasing choices, as regional lawmakers work to make good on a <a href=\"https:\/\/ec.europa.eu\/commission\/presscorner\/detail\/en\/ip_20_420\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Circular Economy Action Plan<\/a> announced two years ago.<\/p>\n<p>The bloc&#8217;s overarching <a href=\"https:\/\/ec.europa.eu\/info\/strategy\/priorities-2019-2024\/european-green-deal_en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">European Green Deal<\/a> plan has the stated goal of making the region &#8220;climate neutral&#8221; by 2050.<\/p>\n<p>That mission translates to no net emissions of greenhouse gases within a time frame of (now) just under three decades while decoupling the EU&#8217;s economic growth from resource use &#8212; aka a shift to a circular economy where products are designed to last longer and also to be easy to disassemble for reuse or recycling at end of life. So there is, very clearly, lots of work for policymakers to do.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291279\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Russia&#8217;s war in Ukraine has only added to the urgency of the EU&#8217;s climate mission &#8212; underscoring the case for the bloc to rapidly move away from using fossil fuels for energy and wider economic fuel as many Member States remain heavily reliant on oil and gas from Russia, leaving their economies exposed to the ongoing regional instability.<\/p>\n<p>In a press release announcing its latest sustainability policy package, the Commission suggests that, by 2030, the revised ecodesign framework could lead to 132 mtoe [million tonnes of oil equivalent] of primary energy savings &#8212; which it emphasizes is &#8220;almost equivalent to EU&#8217;s import of Russian gas&#8221; (which corresponds to &#8220;roughly to 150 bcm [billion cubic meters] of natural gas&#8221;).<\/p>\n<p>It is also keen to flag the value of existing EU ecodesign requirements (which are focused on energy efficiency) &#8212; saying they saved consumers \u20ac120 billion and led to a 10% lower annual energy consumption by the products in scope.<\/p>\n<p>The latest proposals to slot under the EU&#8217;s &#8220;green deal&#8221; umbrella include an interesting idea for Digital Product Passports (see below) &#8212; which is part of a wider push to increase product sustainability via a <a href=\"https:\/\/ec.europa.eu\/environment\/communication-making-sustainable-products-norm_en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Regulation on Ecodesign for Sustainable Products<\/a> (aka ESPR)<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">. <\/span>The latter sets new requirements to &#8220;make products more durable, reliable, reusable, upgradable, reparable, easier to maintain, refurbish and recycle<em>,\u00a0<\/em>and energy and resource efficient&#8221;; and looks set to apply across the board from products such as metals and textiles all the way up to mobile phones and tablets.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;The objective of the Commission&#8217;s Ecodesign proposal is to make sustainable products the norm on the EU market and reduce their overall environmental and climate impacts,&#8221; the EU&#8217;s executive writes, adding: &#8220;The \u2018take-make-use-dispose&#8217; model can be avoided, and much of a product&#8217;s environmental impacts is determined at the design stage.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The ecodesign proposal extends existing EU rules in this area to both broaden the scope of products covered by ecodesign regulations (the Commission says it wants almost all products to fall in scope in the future) and to broaden requirements on those products to encompass circularity and an overall reduction of products&#8217; environmental and climate footprint, in addition to energy efficiency criteria.<\/p>\n<p>So it&#8217;s fair to say that the bloc&#8217;s concept of &#8216;ecodesign&#8217; is being radically redesigned &#8212; and, well, upgraded.<\/p>\n<p>The Commission argues that this broader ecodesign strategy will lead to more energy and resource independence and less pollution, and also anticipates it creating &#8220;economic opportunities for innovation and job creation&#8221;, especially in areas such as remanufacturing, maintenance, recycling and repair. So hot European startups of the future could be in areas like smarter waste management and upcycling.<\/p>\n<p>Specific per product requirements aren&#8217;t clear, as yet, as the EU&#8217;s approach starts with a big picture proposal for a framework and a process &#8212; via which the Commission (&#8220;working in close cooperation with all those concerned&#8221;) will gradually set out requirements for each product or group of products, yielding specific stipulations down the line.<\/p>\n<p>Its approach also suggests there could end up being a degree of variability in requirements across different types of products, as various trade offs (perhaps product longevity vs energy efficiency of manufacture, say) are weighed up and variously assessed in each specific product context. (Variation may also creep in as a result of sector-specific lobbying ofc.)<\/p>\n<div class=\"page\" title=\"Page 5\">\n<div class=\"layoutArea\">\n<div class=\"column\">\n<p>&#8220;These ecodesign requirements will be tailored to the particular characteristics of the product groups concerned,&#8221; the Commission writes in a communication on the proposal. &#8220;Their identification and development will factor-in the potential for improvement and relative effectiveness in delivering increased resource and energy efficiency, enabling longer product life and maximising the value embedded in materials, reducing pollution and the overall impact of products on climate and the <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">environment.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>In a list of sample ecodesign requirements which may apply to different types of products, the communication offers examples that include mandates to minimize waste (such as packaging waste); set a minimum level of recycled content that a product must contain; and require <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">ease of disassembly, remanufacturing and recycling of products and materials, among others.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Only a few sectors, such as food, feed, and medicinal products, are exempted,&#8221; the EU further specifies in a <a href=\"https:\/\/ec.europa.eu\/commission\/presscorner\/detail\/en\/qanda_22_2014\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Q&amp;A<\/a> on the sustainable products initiative which also states that incoming ecodesign and labelling rules will cover product groups which are not regulated now, such as smartphones, tablets and photovoltaic solar systems.<\/p>\n<p>So gadgets look set to fall squarely in scope, along with almost every other type of non-edible thing and\/or material used to make things which may be picked up off a shelf by or dropshipped to an EU consumer in the future (not to mention the packaging itself).<\/p>\n<p>Commenting in a statement, VirginijusSinkevi\u010dius, the EU commissioner for the environment, oceans and fisheries, said:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>Our circular economy proposals kick off an era where products will be designed in a way that brings benefits to all, respects the boundaries of our planet and protects the environment. Giving a longer lifespan to the phones we use, to the clothes we wear and to many other products will save money for European consumers. And at the end of their life products will not be a source of pollution but of new materials for the economy, decreasing the dependency of European businesses on imports.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>The Commission will launch a public consultation on the categories of products to be selected under the first ESPR working plan by the end of this year &#8212; but it suggests the first focus will be on product categories such as textiles, furniture, mattresses, tyres, detergents, paints, lubricants, and on intermediate products like iron, steel and aluminium, as it says these have &#8220;high environmental impact and potential for improvement&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>As the bloc expands ecodesign rules, repairability in general looks set to get a massive boost &#8212; again also for electronics, an area where the Commission already said (<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/11\/european-lawmakers-propose-a-right-to-repair-for-mobiles-and-laptops\/\">March 2020<\/a>) it would be expanding requirements.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Work has advanced significantly with assessing the feasibility of ecodesign requirements and an energy labelling scheme for mobile phones and tablets,&#8221; it notes in a communication on its Ecodesign and Energy Labelling Working Plan, adopted today as a transitory measure &#8220;to cover new energy-related products, update and increase the ambition for products that are already regulated&#8221; until the expanded ecodesign regulation enters into force. <\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;The requirements would be affecting energy efficiency as well as material efficiency (durability, reparability, upgradability and recycling) aspects. The regulations are expected to be adopted before the end of 2022,&#8221; it goes on, adding: &#8220;<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">Likewise, work is well advanced to assess the feasibility of ecodesign requirements and energy labelling for solar photovoltaic modules, inverters and systems, including possible requirements on carbon footprint.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Expanded EU ecodesign rules will apply equally to all products placed on the market, regardless of country of manufacture or importation, meaning gizmos made in Asia or the US that are intended for sale within the bloc won&#8217;t be able to escape compliance with the sustainability requirements.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"n7L5AXRuiZ\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/11\/european-lawmakers-propose-a-right-to-repair-for-mobiles-and-laptops\/\">European lawmakers propose a &#8216;right to repair&#8217; for mobiles and laptops<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;European lawmakers propose a &#8216;right to repair&#8217; for mobiles and laptops&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/03\/11\/european-lawmakers-propose-a-right-to-repair-for-mobiles-and-laptops\/embed\/#?secret=dBuAKMIZAF#?secret=n7L5AXRuiZ\" data-secret=\"n7L5AXRuiZ\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h2>A Digital Product Passport for every thing<\/h2>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>Another part of the EU&#8217;s plan for revised ecodesign rules includes a proposal to introduce Digital Product Passports to store key data to improve traceability around products and support repair\/recycling etc by standardizing the information which product manufacturers must provide.<\/p>\n<p>The Commission also intends these passports to arm consumers with information on environmental impacts to inform purchasing decisions.<\/p>\n<p>This could include energy consumption info but also &#8212; via new EU Energy Labels for relevant products &#8212; a repairability score.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;[P]roduct-specific information requirements will ensure consumers know the environmental impacts of their purchases,&#8221; the Commission suggests of the Digital Product Passport plan. &#8220;All regulated products will have Digital Product Passports. This will make it easier to repair or recycle products and facilitate tracking substances of concern along the supply chain. Labelling can be introduced as well.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Digital product passports <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">will be &#8220;the norm&#8221; for all products regulated under the ESPR, per the Commission &#8212; with the goal to ensure that products are &#8220;tagged, identified and linked to data relevant to their circularity and sustainability&#8221;.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This proposal will&#8230; enable information requirements to be set for products to know more about the impacts of the products on our shelves and make more sustainable choices along the whole value chain,&#8221; it adds.<\/p>\n<p>How exactly this will work isn&#8217;t clear but presumably something like a QR code could be fixed to each product for scanning to view the associated sustainability data.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Digital Product Passports will be rolled out for all regulated products,&#8221; the Commission writes. &#8220;The product information can also take the form of \u2018classes of performance&#8217; &#8212; for instance ranging from \u2018A to G&#8217; &#8212; to facilitate comparison between products, possibly displayed in the form of a label. This would work in a manner similar to how the widely recognized EU Energy Label currently works, and be for instance used for a repairability score.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The EU is also eyeing the potential for this standardized &#8216;metadata&#8217; system to create other data-sharing opportunities &#8212; which could even lead to other types of business opportunity, or support additional pieces of sustainability legislation across the bloc.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;Pioneering this approach for environmental sustainability data can also pave the way for wider voluntary data sharing, going beyond the products and requirements regulated under the ESPR,&#8221; the Commission suggests.<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> &#8220;Moreover, product passports may be used for information on other sustainability aspects applicable to the relevant product group pursuant to other Union legislation.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<div class=\"page\" title=\"Page 6\">\n<div class=\"layoutArea\">\n<div class=\"column\">\n<p>&#8220;Structuring information on the environmental sustainability of products and transmitting it by means of digital product passports will help businesses along the value chain, from manufacturers, importers and distributors to dealers, repairers, remanufacturers and recyclers, to access information that is valuable in their work to improve environmental performance, prolong product lifetime, boost efficiency and the use of secondary raw materials, thus lowering the need for primary natural resources, saving costs and reducing strategic dependencies,&#8221; it also argues.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This will also help track the presence of substances of concern throughout the life cycle of materials and products, following through on commitments made in the Chemicals Strategy for Sustainability and contributing to the EU\u2019s aim to achieve zero pollution. Digital product passports can also enable consumers to make more informed choices, improve transparency for public interest organisations and help national authorities in their enforcement and surveillance work.&#8221;<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<p>Other measures in the EU&#8217;s ecodesign expansion proposal seek to end the destruction of unsold consumer goods &#8212; a practice that can be disturbingly widespread in ecommerce (<a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2021\/6\/21\/22543527\/amazon-unsold-products-destruction-investigation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hi Amazon!<\/a>) and fashion, for example &#8212; through &#8220;far-reaching transparency requirements for those choosing to discard unsold goods, and the possibility to ban their destruction for relevant product groups&#8221;.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;[L]arge businesses that discard unsold products will have to disclose their number per year, the reasons for the discarding and information on the amount of discarded products that they have delivered for preparing for re-use, remanufacturing, recycling, energy recovery and disposal operations in line with the waste hierarchy. They will have to ensure this information is made available, either on a freely accessible website, or via other means,&#8221; the Commission writes.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;This measure will apply to all concerned economic operators as soon as the regulation enters into force. The proposal explicitly prohibits circumvention techniques, such as a big company selling to small companies (which are normally exempted) to make them destroy products.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Green public procurement will also be supported through mandatory criteria in the regulation.<\/p>\n<p>In addition, the Commission has presented two targeted sectoral initiatives today &#8212; one focused on sustainability and circularity of textiles, with the strategy there intended<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> to <\/span>make<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">\u00a0<\/span>textiles<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> &#8220;<\/span>more durable, repairable, reusable and recyclable<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">, to tackle fast fashion, textile waste and the destruction of unsold textiles, and ensure their production takes place in full respect of social rights&#8221; by 2030; and another that aims to boost the internal market for construction products while also ensuring that th<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">e regulatory framework is geared towards <\/span>sustainability and climate objectives<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Both sectors have high carbon footprints.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Ntu8uhkCY3\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/28\/sourceful-series-a\/\">Sourceful grabs $20M to make more packaging less polluting<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Sourceful grabs $20M to make more packaging less polluting&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/28\/sourceful-series-a\/embed\/#?secret=ZLPh5YmXgn#?secret=Ntu8uhkCY3\" data-secret=\"Ntu8uhkCY3\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Rv73ssE42z\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/01\/data-governance-act-provisional-agreement\/\">EU lawmakers agree data reuse rules to foster AI and R&#038;D<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;EU lawmakers agree data reuse rules to foster AI and R&#038;D&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/01\/data-governance-act-provisional-agreement\/embed\/#?secret=VqD4fwE2Ou#?secret=Rv73ssE42z\" data-secret=\"Rv73ssE42z\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The European Union has announced a new bundle of sustainability-focused policy proposals that will expand existing ecodesign rules on energy efficiency by encouraging longer product lifespans, supporting the growth of circular economy business models and helping consumers combat greenwashing and make more environmentally friendly purchasing choices, as regional lawmakers work to make good on a efficiency","slug":"energy-efficiency","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/114868"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=114868"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=114868"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=114868"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=114868"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576912276,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/energy-savings\/","name":"energy savings","slug":"energy-savings","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576912276"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576912276"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576912276"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576912276"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576912276"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291395,"date":"2022-03-30T09:07:30","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:07:30","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291395"},"modified":"2022-03-30T10:11:03","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T17:11:03","slug":"skiff-series-a-encrypted-workspaces","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/skiff-series-a-encrypted-workspaces\/","title":{"rendered":"Skiff lands $10.5M to build out its end-to-end encrypted workspaces"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Six months after <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/26\/skiff-encrypted-collaboration-seed\/\">launching its end-to-end encrypted document editor<\/a>, Skiff has bagged another $10.5 million in fresh funding to build out private and collaborative workspaces for its burgeoning customer base.<\/p>\n<p>We <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/26\/skiff-encrypted-collaboration-seed\/\">wrote about Skiff last year<\/a> ahead of its launch: Skiff is a web app that has much of the same document-writing and sharing capabilities as Google Docs but is built on a foundation of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/end-to-end-encryption\/\">end-to-end encryption<\/a>, so Skiff does not have access to users&#8217; documents like Google does. The startup already has more than 20,000 people using its platform, leaps ahead of the 8,000 waitlisted users it had when we first spoke to the company last May.<\/p>\n<p>But it&#8217;s the end-to-end encryption platform that Skiff relies on that holds the keys to the company&#8217;s future. Now with $10.5 million in Series A funding in the bank, Skiff&#8217;s co-founders Andrew Milich and Jason Ginsberg tell TechCrunch that the company is working toward becoming the &#8220;application layer for the decentralized web.&#8221;<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291395\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>A core part of the company&#8217;s efforts have been on decentralization, a process that allows its users to take ownership of their data. Over the past year Skiff has partnered with Protocol Labs to offer decentralized storage, known as IPFS, or the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/19\/brave-web-browser-adds-native-support-for-peer-to-peer-ipfs-protocol\/\">Interplanetary File System<\/a>, which allows Skiff to encrypt their documents and scatter them across a network of storage hosts, as well as integrating MetaMask, letting users sign in to Skiff using a portable crypto wallet instead of an email address.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;The way we look at it is Web 2.0 is really about moving information around and web3 is about moving value around,&#8221; said Ginsberg, Skiff&#8217;s CTO, in a call. &#8220;Data is the most valuable thing on the internet, and our goal is that you really should own your own data.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Ginsberg said the company is focused on growing its product offering, such as communication, and allowing users to share more kinds of data on its platform.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We see hundreds of millions of people choosing privacy products not really meeting the needs of working together remotely, and so that&#8217;s really where we see Skiff coming in. There&#8217;s tons of different products that we could do along those lines. We&#8217;re most interested right now in exploring products that not just deal with the document side of things, but also the communication side,&#8221; said Ginsberg.<\/p>\n<p>Milich, the startup&#8217;s chief executive, said the round \u2014 led by Sequoia as a returning investor \u2014 will help the company build out those new products that also rely on end-to-end encryption, like communication. Skiff currently has a team of 15 employees dotted across the globe, Milich said. The Series A brings Skiff&#8217;s total funding to about $14 million.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cSkiff is building an amazing team and visionary products to lead this moment,&#8221; said Konstantine Buhler, a partner at Sequoia. &#8220;We couldn\u2019t be more excited to double down.&#8221;<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ovSVa2qy9F\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/26\/skiff-encrypted-collaboration-seed\/\">Skiff, an end-to-end encrypted alternative to Google Docs, raises $3.7M seed<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Skiff, an end-to-end encrypted alternative to Google Docs, raises $3.7M seed&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/26\/skiff-encrypted-collaboration-seed\/embed\/#?secret=NwsyJlSLJN#?secret=ovSVa2qy9F\" data-secret=\"ovSVa2qy9F\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Six months after launching its end-to-end encrypted document editor, Skiff has bagged another $10.5 million in fresh funding to build out private and collaborative workspaces for its burgeoning customer base. We wrote about Skiff last year ahead of its launch: Skiff is a web app that has much of the same document-writing and sharing capabilities \/cto\/","name":"CTO","slug":"cto","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/276453"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=276453"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=276453"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=276453"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=276453"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":6474,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/encryption\/","name":"encryption","slug":"encryption","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/6474"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=6474"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=6474"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=6474"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=6474"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/google\/","name":"Google","slug":"google","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-compan Labs","slug":"protocol-labs","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576596462"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576596462"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576596462"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576596462"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576596462"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":479814,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/sequoia\/","name":"Sequoia","slug":"sequoia","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/479814"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=479814"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=479814"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=479814"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=479814"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":245607,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/sequoia-capital\/","name":"sequoia capital","slug":"sequoia-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/245607"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=245607"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=245607"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=245607"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=245607"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2290053,"date":"2022-03-30T09:01:32","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:01:32","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2290053"},"modified":"2022-03-28T12:19:31","modified_gmt":"2022-03-28T19:19:31","slug":"minut-series-b","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/minut-series-b\/","title":{"rendered":"Minut tells your Airbnb guests to keep it down, already, sheesh"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">You rent out your apartment on Airbnb and the guests are throwing an all-night rager. You only find out three days later when the neighbors are furiously and passive-aggressively putting up signs around the apartment building about &#8220;someone&#8221; throwing loud parties on the third floor. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.minut.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Minut<\/a> just raised $14 million to further expand its privacy-forward &#8220;shhhh, it&#8217;s time to take it down a few notches&#8221; solutions for the hospitality sector.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;I was talking with one of the first employees at Airbnb, when they were at Y Combinator. Even in the very early days, they had an issue: When people are renting out their apartments they have a monitoring need. There was no other option but to put up cameras, and that was turning into a big problem for Airbnb,&#8221; Nils Mattisson, co-founder and CEO of Minut, explains where the idea came from. &#8220;Years later, that idea came back to me. Having been at Apple and having worked with a lot of technologies that were ahead of the times, in terms of combining machine learning and privacy. I first saw how these two came together and how we would be able to solve this problem and balance monitoring and privacy in a good way. So that was the original seed and where we&#8217;ve come back to now, almost 10 years later.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The Minut sensor monitors noise, occupancy, motion and temperature in vacation rental properties. The company sees itself in the role of a co-host, supporting hosts in preventing parties, enhancing the guest experience and protecting their homes.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2290053\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>&#8220;The sensor is about the size of the palm of your hand. It&#8217;s an IoT device &#8212; it&#8217;s got a small computer in there and a bunch of different sensors. Instead of streaming the data to the cloud, we built a solution where analysis is happening on the sensor. And that enables you to use it in cases where you need to respect the privacy of people. That has enabled us to target the short-term rental sector. If you&#8217;re renting out your flat, you want to make sure that you get it back in the same way,&#8221; says Mattisson. &#8220;The value we provide to the host and to the guest is really that we provide monitoring. When we see there are problems with over-occupancy or things that could disturb neighbors, we contact the guests. In over 90% of cases, that means the problem goes away.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Occupancy and room-use monitoring is big business across several sectors, and t<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">here are a number of products on the market that function similarly to Minut. <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/density.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Density<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">, <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/innerspace.io\/beyond-occupancy-data\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">InnerSpace<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> and <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/vergesense.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">VergeSense<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> (the latter of whom recently raised $60 million) are competing for occupancy sensing for office and industrial buildings; in the residential sector, there are a few options, too. <\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">&#8220;We want to help you protect your space, maintain the privacy of your guests, and preserve your relationship with neighbors. This means helping you detect issues in real time,&#8221; <a href=\"https:\/\/www.airbnb.com\/d\/partyprevention\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Airbnb writes<\/a> on its website, recommending<\/span><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">\u00a0Minut, <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/noiseaware.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">NoiseAware<\/a><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> and <\/span><a style=\"background-color: #ffffff; font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\" href=\"https:\/\/roomonitor.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Roomonitor<\/a> as options to its hosts.<\/p>\n<p>Minut is taking an approach of sound analysis on the edge of the network &#8212; in other words, without sending video or audio data to Minut&#8217;s servers. The selling point is to be able to offer near-real-time data, without compromising guest privacy. Minut claims that Airbnb thinks that&#8217;s a very good idea:<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Airbnb is actively promoting responsible and sustainable tourism. Minut\u2019s solution supports Hosts on Airbnb in their efforts to promote trust and safety in their homes and in communities,\u201d Vladimir Beroun, senior manager, Public Policy at Airbnb, is quoted in Minut&#8217;s press release.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The company is selling the sensors relatively cheaply &#8212; at $50 &#8212; with a $150 per year subscription.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;W<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">e are more like a SaaS platform, and we charge a monthly fee per property. We charge for the sensor, but we&#8217;re not really trying to make any money on the hardware side. This business model change is what&#8217;s really enabled this funding round as well. To an investor we look more like a software company,&#8221; says Mattisson. &#8220;On top of the sensor, we are able to build this SaaS platform &#8212; we wouldn&#8217;t be able to do that if we didn&#8217;t have the data underneath.&#8221;<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Minut&#8217;s Series B was led by Almaz Capital, with participation from Zenith, Kompas, Verve Ventures and Swiss Immo Lab. Previous investors Karma, SOSV\u2019s HAX and KPN Ventures also participated. Minut claims it<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\"> has tens of thousands of devices in operation in more than 100 countries. It has offices in the U.S., U.K., Sweden, France and Spain. <\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>You rent out your apartment on Airbnb and the guests are throwing an all-night rager. You only find out three days later when the neighbors are furiously and passive-aggressively putting up signs around the apartment building about &#8220;someone&#8221; throwing loud parties on the third floor. Minut just raised $14 million to further expand its privacy-forward on\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":576788475,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/almaz-capital\/","name":"Almaz Capital","slug":"almaz-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576788475"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576788475"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576788475"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576788475"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576788475"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576685207,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/minut\/","name":"Minut","slug":"minut","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576685207"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576685207"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576685207"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576685207"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576685207"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2290478,"date":"2022-03-30T09:00:38","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:00:38","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2290478"},"modified":"2022-03-31T03:08:36","modified_gmt":"2022-03-31T10:08:36","slug":"equity-and-token-management-startup-sprout-raises-3m","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/equity-and-token-management-startup-sprout-raises-3m\/","title":{"rendered":"Token and equity management startup Sprout raises $3M"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">As cryptocurrency goes mainstream, attracting <a href=\"https:\/\/www.pewresearch.org\/fact-tank\/2021\/11\/11\/16-of-americans-say-they-have-ever-invested-in-traded-or-used-cryptocurrency\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">individual<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2021\/11\/01\/business\/banks-crypto-bitcoin.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">institutional investors<\/a>, digitally-savvy employers realize tokens are an increasingly attractive form of compensation, especially for their millennial staff.<\/p>\n<p>But paying employees in digital assets can create all sorts of administrative hurdles. Human resources managers manually record who has been paid what on a giant Excel sheet but can easily lose track of where the tokens are going, as transactions are largely decentralized. And because token holders are also supposed to be shareholders in an organization, changes of ownership can tip the control and power within the company.<\/p>\n<p>Started three years ago, Sprout is trying to make the ownership of digital assets more traceable and transparent for organizations. The Hong Kong-based startup was founded by Andy Lee and Tony Sun, who used to work together at Mapbox, as a cap table software provider. It was helping mid-size startups keep track of equity as they grew, but last summer, as the price of Bitcoin shot to a historic high, the company began getting requests from its clients to help manage employee tokens.<\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2290478\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Sprout created Folium in light of this customer demand to help companies trace digital coins and non-fungible tokens across various blockchain platforms. Folium begins by collecting individuals&#8217; blockchain addresses, reading ledger changes and labeling them according to ownership, like whether it belongs to an employee, investor or founder, and the type of transactions; that is, whether it&#8217;s a payroll or investment.<\/p>\n<p>Once all the wallets are tagged, Sprout will have a token cap table ready just as it has done for equity ownership. Tracking tokens gives more transparency to founders, investors and ultimately regulators, reckoned Lee.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;We think there&#8217;s a tremendous opportunity to help traditional and crypto companies manage tokens,&#8221; said Lee, who previously worked on Uber&#8217;s business development across Asia, including China. &#8220;Crypto is next-generation compensation.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Sprout has hit a sweet spot managing both traditional equity and the flourishing space of digital tokens via its SaaS platform. With this two-thronged strategy in place, the startup managed to raise $3 million from a seed funding round that recently closed.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Investors from the round included Sequoia Capital India, U.S.-based venture funds Sovereign\u2019s Capital and Firsthand Ventures, as well as Hong Kong&#8217;s NDN2 and the special administrative region&#8217;s government-backed funds. Prominent angel investor Ruby Lu, who is known for her early bet on Kuaishou, TikTok&#8217;s nemesis in China, also participated.<\/p>\n<p>Sprout is first going after companies in Hong Kong and Singapore, which have emerged as major nexus for crypto companies. &#8220;There are, anecdotally, a lot of employees and people in the Asia Pacific who understand tokens more than equity,&#8221; Lee observed. &#8220;So it&#8217;s actually attractive for a company [in the region] to think about, especially if they&#8217;re moving into web3, having tokens.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>With its new proceeds, Sprout plans to add more product and engineering staff to its current team of 30 and expand in Singapore. The company declined to mention how many customers it&#8217;s servicing but said Hong Kong-based microinsurance firm YAS Digital and crypto gaming company Animoca Brands are among its early users.<\/p>\n<p><em>The article was updated to clarify that Sequoia didn&#8217;t lead the round.<\/em><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"aP9cOhfJlS\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/09\/tokens-can-better-incentivize-startup-employees-than-equity\/\">Tokens can better incentivize startup employees than equity<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"&#8220;Tokens can better incentivize startup employees than equity&#8221; &#8212; TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/09\/tokens-can-better-incentivize-startup-employees-than-equity\/embed\/#?secret=VBbQbiHXJz#?secret=aP9cOhfJlS\" data-secret=\"aP9cOhfJlS\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n<p><audio style=\"display: none;\" controls=\"controls\"><\/audio><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>As cryptocurrency goes mainstream, attracting individual and institutional investors, digitally-savvy employers realize tokens are an increasingly attractive form of compensation, especially for their millennial staff. But paying employees in digital assets can create all sorts of administrative hurdles. Human resources managers manually record who has been paid what on a giant Excel sheet but can [&hellip;]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":133574232,"featured_media":2265845,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"1c25ff48-d97d-3c60-9554-d7eaff77db9e"},"categories":[449557111,576602837,576601119,15835174,576602978,576602979,20429,17396],"tags":[576609063,35796,36507086,226336030,449557076,576596953,25818,284712,25473327,576668608,58907990,2915702,4114631,613,161318,449557042,5938293,217609,422971354],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/02\/GettyImages-1238043969.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/equity-and-token-management-startup-sprout-raises-3m\/"},"headline":"Token technology","slug":"financial-technology","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576668608"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576668608"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576668608"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576668608"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576668608"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2291388,"date":"2022-03-30T09:00:28","date_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:00:28","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2291388"},"modified":"2022-03-30T09:54:13","modified_gmt":"2022-03-30T16:54:13","slug":"chrome-os-gets-a-new-launcher-for-its-100th-birthday","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/30\/chrome-os-gets-a-new-launcher-for-its-100th-birthday\/","title":{"rendered":"Chrome OS gets a new launcher for its 100th birthday"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">The Chrome OS team is launching version 100 of its lightweight operating system today and with that, it&#8217;s bringing quite a few interesting changes to the platform. The most obvious one is a new launcher, which is moving from the bottom to the side of the screen and getting a few more new features. The built-in camera app now also lets you save your creations as a GIF and the Chrome OS dictation feature now makes it easier to edit your text. Also new is support for more than 100 additional devices for the newly launched <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/15\/google-wants-to-bring-chrome-os-to-your-pc-or-mac\/\">Chrome OS Flex<\/a>. For developers, Google is launching a redesigned <a href=\"http:\/\/chromeos.dev\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ChromeOS.dev<\/a> site.<\/p>\n<p>The launcher is likely the first thing users will notice. Mind you, the taskbar itself isn&#8217;t moving, we&#8217;re just talking about Chrome OS&#8217;s equivalent of the Windows Start menu. Google says the idea here is to leave more space for other windows you have open. Users can now organize their apps by name or color (if that&#8217;s your thing) or manually arrange them in any order that makes sense to you (or you can be like me and just opt for chaos).<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291392\" style=\"width: 610px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Launcher.gif\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291392\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291392\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Launcher.gif\" alt=\"Google Chrome OS new launcher\" width=\"600\" height=\"400\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291392\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p><div id=\"tc-target-mid-article-2291388\" class=\"tc-target-mid-article ad-unit--size-auto\"><\/div>\n<p>Inside the launcher, Google has updated the search feature, which previously showed a brief preview of the search result. After this update, you&#8217;ll get to see quite a bit more information, even before you head into the browser. Shortcuts are also now integrated into this search experience, so you can easily take a screenshot, for example.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291462\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291462\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291462\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"782\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png 1228w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png?resize=150,115 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png?resize=300,229 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png?resize=768,587 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png?resize=680,519 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Text-Dictation-Editing.png?resize=50,38 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291462\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>As for voice editing, the experience here is what you would expect. You can now say &#8220;delete&#8221; to delete the last letter, for example, or &#8220;move to next character&#8221; to move the cursor. Pretty straightforward, to the point where one has to wonder why these features weren&#8217;t there before, but definitely a very useful addition for users who rely on dictation.<\/p>\n<p>The GIF creation in the Chromebook Camera explains itself. There is now a new toggle to turn it on and once you&#8217;ve done that, you can create a five-second GIF.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2291413\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Gif-maker.gif\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2291413\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2291413\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Gif-maker.gif\" alt=\"Chrome OS Gif maker\" width=\"1024\" height=\"676\" \/><\/a><p id=\"caption-attachment-2291413\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>The Chrome OS team is launching version 100 of its lightweight operating system today and with that, it&#8217;s bringing quite a few interesting changes to the platform. The most obvious one is a new launcher, which is moving from the bottom to the side of the screen and getting a few more new features. The
